content.user_title: Write reliable shell scripts with best practices
content.value_statement: Shell scripts often fail silently or behave unpredictably due to missing error handling. This skill provides battle-tested patterns for robust bash and zsh scripting including proper error handling, safe variable expansion, and modular code structure.
actual_capabilities: Apply safe script structure with set -euo pipefail
Implement proper error handling with trap and exit codes
Use safe variable expansion and default values
Process text with find, awk, sed, and jq patterns
Create modular scripts with functions and constants
Build CLI tools with argument parsing and help output
limitations: Does not execute scripts on your system
Does not provide ready-to-run script templates
Does not install or configure shell environments

prompt_templates.title: Error handling patterns
prompt_templates.scenario: Add error handling to a script

output_examples.input: Write a bash script that processes CSV files safely
output: Use IFS=, to properly split CSV columns
Check file exists before reading with [[ -f "$file" ]]
Handle empty lines and malformed data gracefully
Use set -euo pipefail for robust error handling

output_examples.input: How do I handle errors in my shell scripts
output: Use set -euo pipefail at script start
Check command exit codes explicitly with if ! command
Use trap for cleanup on EXIT, INT, and TERM
Provide meaningful error messages with exit codes

output_examples.input: Create a script that finds large files and reports them
output: Use find with -size option for file size filtering
Process results with while read loop for safety
Generate timestamped reports with date formatting
Handle spaces in filenames with proper quoting
Add verbose mode for debugging output

best_practices: Always use set -euo pipefail and quote all variable expansions to prevent silent failures
Implement cleanup handlers with trap for temporary files and resources
Validate all inputs and check command exit codes explicitly
anti_patterns: Avoid parsing ls output - use globs and find instead
Never use eval with untrusted or user-supplied input
Do not assume paths are safe - always quote and validate

faq.question: What shells does this skill support?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on bash and zsh, which are the most common shells for scripting on Linux and macOS systems.

faq.question: What are the key error handling options?
faq.answer: set -e (exit on error), set -u (error on undefined vars), and set -o pipefail (catch pipe failures) are the core options.

faq.question: How does this skill integrate with Claude Code?
faq.answer: Request shell scripting guidance using natural language. The skill provides patterns you can apply directly in your scripts.

faq.question: Is this skill safe to use?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only provides guidance and patterns. It does not execute code or modify files on your system.

faq.question: Why does my script fail silently?
faq.answer: Without set -euo pipefail, bash continues on errors. Add these options and check exit codes explicitly for reliable scripts.

faq.question: How is this different from AI code generators?
faq.answer: This skill teaches patterns and best practices. Use it to understand shell scripting or request specific patterns rather than generating complete scripts.
